src: po leelo ɪ-m-bwele \textbf{j}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{lond}-\textbf{aga} ʊkʊtɪ jɪ-j-eeg-e ɪ-m-bʊlʊkʊtʊ
trs: So, Mosquito wanted to marry Ear.
So Mosquito went to Ear.
Yesterday, when I heard the cows making a lot of noise, I got up.

src: bo n-nw-ile ɪɪ-t͜ʃai n-aa-bʊʊk-a kʊ-kʊ-kam-a ʊ-lʊ-kama
trs: (intended: \lq Yesterday I got up very early. I had breakfast (lit. \lq drank tea'). When I finished breakfast, I went to milk the cows …') [ET]}
\lq Right here it ended.' [Throw away the child]
\lq The story is over' [Man and his in-law]

src: ɪ-n-gwina n=ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ ba-a-lɪ bʊ-manyaani fiijo a-ka-balɪlo a-k-a ijolo. ba-a-jaat-an-il-aga n=ʊ-kw-angal-a pamopeene. ɪ-n-gwina j-iis-aga n-kʊ-j-eeg-a ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ n=ʊ-kʊ-bʊʊk-a na=jo pa-lʊ-sʊngo pa-kw-angal-a. ii-sikʊ lɪ-mo ʊ-n-na gw-a n-gwina a-a-lɪ m̩-bine
trs: \lq Monkey and Crocodile were good friends long ago. They visited and accompanied each other. Crocodile used to come to pick up monkey and go with him to an island to spend time together. One day, Crocodile's mother was sick.

src: po ɪ-n-gwina \textbf{j}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{bʊʊk}-\textbf{ile} n-kʊ-jɪ-bʊʊl-a ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ ʊkʊtɪ \textup{\lq\lq}jʊʊba gw-angʊ m̩-bine. tʊ-bʊʊk-e ʊ-ka-n-keet-e.\textup{''}
trs: \lq So Crocodile went to tell Monkey, \lq\lq My mother is sick. Let's go, you should see her.''{}
\lq Monkey agreed.
\lq They went.' [Crocodile and Monkey]
\lq They loaded the grass on their heads.
\lq They went.

src: po bo bi-kw-end-a bi-kw-end-a po \textbf{ba}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{fik}-\textbf{ile} pa-mo a-pa b-end-aga
trs: \lq As they were going and going they arrived at some place where they were going.

src: ba-lɪnkʊ-ky-ag-a ɪ-k-iina ɪ-kɪ ki-kʊ-job-igw-a ʊkʊtɪ kɪ-sooko, ɪ-kɪ-tali fiijo
trs: \lq They found a cave which is called a ravine, a deep one.
\lq This one betrayed her friend.' [Throw away the child]
Then Skunk became tired.
He began to doze.

src: po bo i-kʊ-sipʊk-a, bo a-gon-ile ʊ-tʊ-lo po kalʊlʊ a-aly-eg-ile ɪɪ-nyama j-oosa
trs: ‎‎As he was dozing, as he was asleep, Hare took all the meat.
He ate it up, he ate it up.

src: bo i-kʊ-lembʊk-a nsyɪsyɪ a-lɪnkw-ag-a kalʊlʊ a-l-iile j-oosa ɪɪ-nyama
trs: When Skunk woke up, he found that Hare had eaten all of the meat.

src: po a-lɪnkʊ-mmw-ani-a kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}ɪɪ-nyama jɪ-bʊʊk-ile kʊʊgʊ?\textup{''}
trs: So he asked Hare ``The meat, where has it gone?''{}

src: po kalʊlʊ a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}hee. n-aa-gon-eliile niine ʊ-tʊ-lo. keet-a, jɪ-p-iile j-oosa, jɪ-bwes-ile. jɪ-bwes-ile, hee\textup{''}'
trs: Hare said ``Hee, I was also asleep. Look, it all burnt to ashes. It burnt, hee.'
Skunk was very angry.' % hier erst, oder vorher schon?
He said ``OK!''{}' [Hare and Skunk]
\lq Yesterday we spoke.'}
We did not speak.
(intended: \lq When I am grown up, I will build a big house. Then I will herd cows at home.')}

src: Asia a-lɪnkʊ-sʊʊbɪl-a ʊkʊtɪ Juma aa=i-kʊ-j-a n̩-dʊme gw-ake
trs: \lq Asia expected that Juma would become her husband.
\lq Gosh, he has moved to Sambuka's, without knowing [that Sambuka has lied to him].'\footnotemark
\lq Juma and Sambuka married.' [Juma, Asia and Sambuka]

src: bo bi-kʊ-lond-a ʊ-kʊ-kɪnd-a kʊkʊtɪ bi-kʊ-tɪ ba-jɪ-tambʊk-e ba-kɪnd-e \textbf{jɪ}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{tup}-\textbf{a} kangɪ \textbf{jɪ}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{j}-\textbf{a} n-dali
trs: \lq As they tried to pass, each time they wanted to cross and pass it [snake], it became fat and long.' [Children and Snake]

src: Sambʊka \textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{hobok}-\textbf{a} fiijo paapo ɪ-si a-a-lond-aga a-a-sy-ag-ile
trs: \lq  Sambuka became very happy because she had achieved what she wanted.' [Juma, Asia and Sambuka]

imt: then now/but as 1-arrive-\textsc{pfv} near 16-7-cave or 16-room(9) 9-\textsc{assoc} 9-lion tortoise(1) 1-\textsc{narr}-stand/stop-\textsc{fv} 16-outside
src: po leelo bo a-fik-ile kɪfuki pa-k-iina pamo paa-sofu j-aa n-galamu kajamba \textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪnkw}-\textbf{ɪm}-\textbf{a} pa-nja
trs: \lq When it arrived near the cave or the bedroom of Lion, Tortoise stopped outside.' [Lion and Tortoise]
\lq They went to pluck grass there.
\lq They plucked grass.
\lq She took her child.
\lq She then did what, began to breastfeed it.

src: jʊ-la a-lɪnkw-and-a ʊ-kʊ-buj-a ʊ-kʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-kʊ-n-keet-a ʊ-mw-anaake
trs: \lq That one began returning, going to look for her child.' [Throw away the child]
\lq He [Tugutu] said \lq\lq Here we go, Hare! Let's run now!'
\lq Hare ran/was running.

src: a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}lɪnga tʊ-bop-ile a-ma-elɪ jɪ-mo n-gʊ-kʊ-koolel-a ʊkutɪ \textup{\lq\lq}bʊle, mwa=n-dugutu, ʊ-li-po?\textup{''} gw-itɪk-e ʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}ee, n-di=po\textup{''{}''}
trs: \lq He said \lq\lq When we've run one mile, I'll call you saying \lq\lq Mr. Tugutu are you there?'' You shall answer \lq\lq Yes, I'm here.''{}''{}'\footnote{The narrator oscillates between placing the loanword for \lq mile' in noun class 6, thus re-analyzing /ma/ as a prefix, and placing it in noun class 9a, the default for loans.}

src: po bo b-and-ile ʊ-kʊ-bop-a jʊ-la mwa=n-dugutu a-a-syeele pala$\sim$pa-la
trs: ‎\lq When they had started to run that Mr. Tugutu had remained right there.
\lq So Hare ran/was running alone.
\lq He completed one mile.' [Hare and Tugutu]

src: a-lɪnkʊ-n-koolel-a ʊ-n-kasi, a-lɪnkʊ-tɪ \textup{\lq\lq}n-kasi gw-angʊ, bʊʊk-e lɪlɪno ʊlʊ, k-ʊʊl-e ɪ-fi-lombe, ʊ-ka-sy-e ʊ-bʊ-fu, kʊ-ma-lʊʊka\textup{''}
trs: He called his wife and said ``My wife, go right now, go buy maize, go grind flour, in the stores.''{}
She went and bought maize.
She went and ground flour at the stores.

src: kʊ-no ʊ-n̩-dʊme \textbf{a}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{tendekesy}-\textbf{a} ʊ-tʊ-ndʊ, ɪ-fi-lwɪlo fy-a kʊ-n̩-gog-el-a ʊ-gwise
trs: Here her husband prepared things, poison to kill her father with.
Then that young woman returned.' [Man and his in-law]
\lq They walked, they walked, they walked.
\lq They said \lq\lq Eh, we're tired.''{}' [Throw away the child]
They caught (the bottles) in mid air.

src: ɪ-m-bilipili jɪ-lɪnkʊ-sunyunduk-a n-tʊ-supa mu-la n=ʊ-kʊ-nyeel-el-a m-maa-so na m-mi-lomo
trs: The pepper came out of the little bottles and flew into their eyes and mouths.

src: popaa$\sim$po ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ \textbf{si}-\textbf{lɪnkʊ}-\textbf{gw}-\textbf{a} paa-si paapo j-aa-lɪ n-galɪ fiijo
trs: And so the monkeys fell down because it was very hot.
‎‎They cried and said, ``Ho! Ho! Ho!''{}
Some fell down, ``Splat!''{}' [Thieving monkeys]
(intended: \lq When I am grown up, I will build a big house. Then I will herd cows at home.')}

src: bo m-mal-ile pa-kʊ-kin-a \textbf{n}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{bʊʊk}-\textbf{a} kʊ-n-nuguna gw-angʊ kʊ-kʊ-ly-a nagwe ɪ-fi-ndʊ fy-a pa-muu-si
trs: (intended: \lq Tomorrow I will play football. When I am done playing, I will go to my younger brother to have lunch with him.')}
(intended: \lq Long ago they used to dance a lot. They dressed well. They bathed. They combed their hair \ldots')}

src: po piitaasi ʊ-n-nyambala jʊ-la a-lɪnkʊ-j-a mu-ndʊ gw-a kʊ-fung-a ɪɪ-safalɪ j-aake j-aa kʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-no ba-li=ko ba-la, kʊ-kʊ-mel-a ɪ-fy-ʊma
trs: \lq Then later that man started to set out for where they were, in order to claim the brideprice.
\lq When he arrived there, they received him well.
\lq He ate.
\lq He slept.

src: po \textbf{kɪ}-\textbf{laabo} \textbf{a}-\textbf{mmw}-\textbf{eg}-\textbf{a} ʊ-n-kyameni n=ʊ-kʊ-m̩-bʊʊl-a ɪ-si si-n-twele pa-la
trs: \lq The next day he contacted  a chairman and told him what brought him there.' [Man and his in-law]

src: po ba-lɪnkw-and-a b-oope bo bʊ-k-iile n=ʊ-lʊ-bʊnjʊ
trs: \lq Early in the morning they started.
\lq They began to bath.
\lq They got dressed up.

src: ba-lɪnkʊ-j-a b-andʊ ba-a kʊ-piny-a ɪ-mi-sigo gy-abo n=ʊ=kʊ-bʊʊk-a
trs: \lq They began to bind their things and go.
\lq Ngoosi lifted that flour.
\lq She loaded it on her head.' [Man and his in-law]

src: b-oosa ba-bɪlɪ ba-lɪnkʊ-j-a ba-ndʊ ba-a kʊ-bʊʊk-a m̩-bʊ-ganga
trs: The two of them set out to go to a healer.

src: boo=bʊno$\sim$bʊ-no ba-lɪnkw-end-a, ba-lɪnkw-end-a, ba-lɪnkw-end-a, ba-lɪnkw-end-a n=ʊ-kw-end-a
trs: Thus they travelled, travelled, travelled and travelled.
Finally they arrived in some land.' [Pregnant women]
\lq They continued their journey.
\lq Thus they continued.
They got further ahead.' [Man and his in-law]
\lq Mr. Tugutu went.
\lq He gathered five companions \ldots

src: bo ii-sikʊ ly-a kɪ-laabo, bo lɪ-fik-ile, mwa=n-dugutu a-alɪ-m̩-bɪɪk-ile mwa=n-dugutu n-nine pa-bw-andɪlo
trs: \lq When the next day arrived, Mr. Tugutu placed a fellow Mr. Tugutu at the start.

src: kangɪ maelɪ jɪ-ngɪ jɪ-mo a-alɪ-m̩-bɪɪk-ile mwa=n-dugutu n-nine \ldots
trs: \lq Another mile, he placed a fellow Mr. Tugutu \ldots

src: na kʊ-lʊ-malɪɪkɪlo, ma-elɪ ga-a bʊ-haano mwa=n-dugutu ʊ-jʊ-ngɪ
trs: \lq At the finish line, the fifth mile, another Mr. Tugutu.

src: po mwa=n-dugutu ʊ-jʊ-ngɪ, jʊ-la ba-a-job-aga na kalʊlʊ \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{j}-\textbf{a} pa-bw-andɪlo pa-la
trs: \lq  ‎‎The other Mr. Tugutu, the one who had been talking with Hare, he then was at the start.' [Hare and Tugutu]

src: ɪ-li-sikʊ lɪ-mo, ɪ-n-gʊlʊbe j-aa-bɪɪk-ɪl-iigwe ɪ-fi-ndʊ fy-ake
trs: One day, Pig was given its food.

src: po leelo ɪ-li-seekwa \textbf{ly}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{salaga}$\sim$\textbf{sal}-\textbf{aga} ʊ-kʊ-lond-a ɪ-fi-ndʊ fy-a kw-i-swɪl-a ly-ope
trs: Duck was pecking for food to feed itself.
Then it saw Pig's food.

src: ba-lɪnkw-abʊl-a, ba-lɪnkʊ-gw-ag-a ʊ-n-tʊ gw-a gwise gw-a n̩goosi gʊ-li=ko kʊ-bʊ-fu bʊ-la
trs: They opened it [sack], they found that Ngoosi's father's head was in that flour.

src: ʊ-n-nyambala jʊ-la \textbf{a}-\textbf{a}-\textbf{lond}-\textbf{aga} ʊ-kʊ-bop-a, ʊ-n̩-dʊme gw-a n̩goosi
trs: That man, Ngoosi's husband, was trying to run away.
They caught him right there.
They killed him.' [Man and his in-law]
\lq He [Pig] ran.
\lq He broke Duck's head.
The livestock owner ran.
He took a knife.
He slaughtered Duck.' [Pig and Duck]

src: ʊ-gwise gw-a n̩goosi, ʊ-n-nyambala jʊ-la, a-a-tʊʊgal-aga n-ky-umba ky-ake pasima
trs: Ngoosi's father, that man's father in-law, he was staying in a separate room.
In that room he was all alone.

src: po mw-ene n̩goosi na jʊ-n̩-dʊme ba-a-j-aga n=ɪ-ky-umba ky-abo
trs: Ngoosi and her husband, they had their own room.

src: po p-ii-balasi pa-la \textbf{j}-\textbf{aa}-\textbf{j}-\textbf{a}=\textbf{po} ɪɪ-meesa a-pa paa$\sim$pa n̩goosi a-a-tʊʊl-ile ʊ-bʊ-fu bw-ake
trs: On the veranda there was a table where Ngoosi had put the flour.' [Man and his in-law]
\lq He [Monkey] snatched the grindstone.
\lq He ran with that grindstone.'%\clearpage
\lq He went [=ran] into the bush.' [Monkey and Tortoise]
\lq Tortoise's child said \lq\lq Thanks.''{}
\lq They entered the farm.
\lq They took cocoyam.
\lq They took a side dish.
\lq They took all sorts of food.' [Monkey and Tortoise]
\lq She called to the men, \lq\lq She's devoured the children!''{}
\lq [Some of the] men began to run.
\lq They [some other men] began to run.
\lq They [some other men] began to run.' [Python and woman]
